column2: Amber Heard is abusive.  Johnny Depp is a great actor.
column33: Warner Brothers: Keep Johnny Depp as Grindelwald
column34:
Johnny Depp was sadly forced to step down as our beloved Grindelwald in the Fantastic Beasts franchise. 

This was all done because he lost his case to clear his name, with proof, on the accusations brought forth courtesy of Amber Heard. 

When the news broke out, fans were in a very righteous uproar. Johnny Depp's career shouldn't be derailed under false pretenses. 

Only, I repeat, only Johnny Depp can pull off our beloved Fantastic Beasts villian Grindelwald. 

Johnny Depp is Grindelwald.

column2:
What kind of world do we actually live in? We live in a world where violent males are commiserated, excused and even hailed as real men and heroes. There are enough examples, especially in the celebrity world.

Norman Mailer, William S. Burroughs, Roman Polanski, Louis Althusser, Peter Handke, David Bowie, Jimmy Page and Phil Spector, who died just a few days ago.
What do these authors, actors, philosophers, musicians, directors, producers and many others whose names were collected under a long thread last week by writer and 54books editor Berit Glanz have in common? They hit, sexually abused, raped or killed women or girls, it became known and they then continued their careers largely without problems, sometimes to this day. Most are revered as geniuses and important artists. This selection is only about the most famous ones; the list on Twitter is longer and not exhaustive either. Many of them talked about it, put their actions into perspective or, after years, publicly regretted it as a big mistake, some were finally sentenced, and apart from Spector, hardly any of them had to go to prison for a really long time.

The exact circumstances of Joan Vollmer Adams' death will probably remain unclear forever. However, the undisputed fact is that her husband at the time, the writer William S. Burroughs, shot her dead on September 6, 1951 in Mexico City.
Early in the morning on November 19, 1960, at a party celebrating his candidacy for mayor of the city of New York, the famous writer Norman Mailer stabbed his wife twice with a knife during an argument, and the wife survived with serious injuries. He was given a suspended sentence after Adele Morales dropped the charges.
Violence and the murder of women and girls are recurring cultural themes, not only in the works of men who themselves became violent, although it can be assumed that many cases are unknown. On the contrary, misogynistic violence is everywhere in our culture, in songs, in films, in series, in novels and in documentaries and true crime stories about serial killers. Murdered and abused women permeate cultural history so much to this day that one has to ask oneself, in view of the cases listed, how reality and fiction are connected. Because not infrequently, the murderous or violent man in fiction is the exciting and disreputable fascination that one should not find fascinating in reality.
Particularly perfidious is a case like the rape of the then nineteen-year-old actress Maria Schneider by the much older Marlon Brando in front of the camera during the shooting of The Last Tango in Paris, a scene that was previously created by director Bernardo Bertolucci and Brando for the sake of supposed authenticity had been planned and which can be seen in the film. This is where the reality of misogynist violence meets the fiction of the seemingly broken man Brando is meant to portray in the film in a repulsive way. In the collusion between the director and his actor about the rape, what is otherwise hidden behind the facade of allegedly repentant violent criminals comes to light: violence against women and girls is seen by many artists as well as their audience as proof of authentic, broken men's souls . Nothing else should convey the rape of Schneider in Last Tango in Paris. The young woman was a means to an end. The misogynistic violence is stylized as the proverbial battered male soul's struggle with itself, instead of acknowledging that hatred of women should not be a source of artistic inspiration.

Many male violent offenders and not only partners, husbands, but also many well-known serial killers, serial rapists, stalkers such as Ted Bundy or Rodney James Alcala are psychopaths and narcissists. This is a highly dangerous mixture.
For example: Track and field athlete Oscar Pistorius from South Africa shot his female partner Reeva Steenkamp and was convicted of murder. Would Pistorius have taken up arms against another woman at some point? Probably for sure.
Of course, a narcissist can also have a harmonious relationship if they find a partner with a corresponding disorder. Those who are willing to acknowledge the narcissist's unchallenged mastery can live with them. But as soon as a narcissist meets someone who claims the right to have their own opinion, things get critical. Another example is Johnny Depp, the famous American actor, who waged an outright hate and defamation campaign against his ex-wife  Amber Heard despite being convicted of extraordinary violence. When celebrities split up, tatters often fly; Johnny Depp is said to have hit his ex-wife Amber Heard or Brad Pitt to have abused the children he raised with Angelina Jolie. These men are famous, celebrated and yet living with them is highly dangerous and not recommended for any woman. The victims are generally defamed, ridiculed, accused of being insane or a liar around the world. This affects celebrity and non-celebrity women worldwide. We should put an end to the vicious games of violent males by condemning them and listening to their victims with compassion. It would be so easy and that's what women around the world wish for in the future.
